results.abstract: Team of New York City firefighters devises rope escape system from burning building five months afer two collegues jumped to their deaths in Bronx fire; firefighters used their off-duty skills in rock climbing and metalworking to build system; Fire Dept is preparing to give each firefighter new rope escape system, saying it will make New York only large city to provide all firefighters with rope and anchor to use if they must jump out of window to avoid advancing flames; system described; photos diagram (M)

headline.main: Wanting a Safer Escape System, City Firefighters Build Their Own

results.snippet: Less than five months after a Bronx fire forced two firefighters to jump to their deaths, the Fire Department is preparing to give firefighters a costly rope escape system.
results.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

multimedia.caption: A Better Way to Get Out
multimedia.credit: The Fire Department plans to outfit firefighters with a unique personal escape system designed to allow escape from a burning building in 10 seconds.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: The Fire Department plans to outfit firefighters with a unique personal escape system designed to allow escape from a burning building in 10 seconds.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline2: A Better Way to Get Out

multimedia.caption: Better Ropes for Firefighters
multimedia.credit: Less than five months after a Bronx fire forced two firefighters to jump to their deaths, the Fire Department is preparing a costly rope escape system.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Less than five months after a Bronx fire forced two firefighters to jump to their deaths, the Fire Department is preparing a costly rope escape system.

results.lead_paragraph: Less than five months after a Bronx fire forced two firefighters to jump to their deaths, the New York Fire Department is preparing to give each firefighter a costly rope escape system that was largely designed by a team of city firefighters using their off-duty skills in rock climbing and metalworking. Department officials say the escape systems, which they hope firefighters will be using by September, will make New York the nation's only large city to provide all firefighters with a rope and anchor to use if they must jump out a window to avoid advancing flames.

headline.main: In Start of Expected Shake-Up, An Official at NASA Resigns

results.snippet: The resignation is the first in what are expected to be dozens of resignations or reassignments as the new administrator asserts his control over the agency.
results.lead_paragraph: A NASA official who led efforts to develop the next generation of spacecraft has announced his resignation, the first in what are expected to be dozens of resignations or reassignments as the new administrator, Michael D. Griffin, asserts his control over the agency. In recent days, NASA headquarters has sent out dozens of letters to officials letting them know that they will be reassigned or will have to leave the agency, and has canceled a closely watched contract with a company that had been brought in to improve the agency's much-criticized safety culture.

headline.main: Dead Guardsmen's Families Must Mourn and Wonder, Too

results.snippet: The friends and family of two New York National Guardsmen who were killed in Iraq said that their grief would be compounded by confusion until the military finished its criminal investigation into how they died.
results.lead_paragraph: The friends and family of two New York National Guardsmen who were killed in Iraq on Tuesday said yesterday that their grief would be compounded by confusion until the military finished its criminal investigation into how they died. Joan Esposito, the mother of one of the soldiers, Capt. Phillip T. Esposito, 30, of Suffern, N.Y., said her son's wife, Siobhan, should be given a clear account of his death as soon as possible. ''I just want what's right for my daughter-in-law,'' Ms. Esposito said. ''She needs answers.''

headline.main: War on Terror Dominates Talks Given at Graduations

results.snippet: Many commencement speakers emphasized that this year's graduating class was the first whose entire university career unfolded in the post 9-11 world.
results.lead_paragraph: Congresswoman Eleanor Holmes Norton addressed an audience of graduates in New Haven this spring as ''you who entered Yale as the twin towers fell.'' Many other commencement speakers, including Tom Hanks, also emphasized that this year's graduating class was the first whose entire university career unfolded in the post 9-11 world. ''None of you were untouched by the events in September of your freshmen year, none unaffected by the ideological movements of local and geopolitics since,'' Mr. Hanks told Vassar graduates.

headline.main: When Astronauts Brief Congress, A Little Levity Goes a Long Way

results.snippet: With his remarks coming from 218 miles above Earth, Dr. John L. Phillips became the first person in history to deliver Congressional testimony from space.
results.lead_paragraph: As members of Congress questioned three witnesses at a hearing on Tuesday, one of those testifying shifted his feet, and his legs floated up above his head. Two of the witnesses, NASA astronauts who have served long tours on the International Space Station, sat at a hearing table while the third loomed behind them on a video screen. With his remarks coming from 218 miles above Earth, Dr. John L. Phillips, 54, became the first person in history to deliver Congressional testimony from space.

headline.kicker: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: NEW YORK GUARDSMAN
headline.main: Guardsman Charged in Deaths Of 2 Superiors at Iraq Base

results.snippet: The United States military charged a New York Army National Guard member with murdering his commanding officers last week at a base in Tikrit.

byline.original: By MICHELLE O'DONNELL and DAMIEN CAVE; Kirk Semple contributed reporting for this article

results.lead_paragraph: The United States military charged a New York Army National Guard member yesterday with murdering his commanding officers last week at a base near Tikrit, Iraq. The officers, Capt. Phillip T. Esposito, 30, and First Lt. Louis E. Allen, 34, of the 42nd Infantry Division, New York Army National Guard, were first believed to have died after indirect fire hit the window of a building they were in on June 7.

headline.main: Sizzle on Your Head: Lasers for Baldness

results.snippet: Lasers won't bring back follicles. But they might rejuvenate failing ones.
results.lead_paragraph: WITH the practiced Ã©lan of an astronaut donning his space helmet before a launching, Neil Greenberg pulls a capsule the size and shape of a large breadbox over his head and turns it on. Mr. Greenberg is the proprietor of Natural Image, what is called a nonsurgical hair restoration salon, in Plymouth Meeting, Pa. ''Don't worry, this is completely safe,'' he says as his chin and mouth glow red beneath the device's rim. ''There's virtually no sensation at all.''

headline.main: A Vision of Stars, Grounded in the Dust of Rural India

results.snippet: A 17-year-old who dreams of a career with NASA tempers his aspirations with hard work.

byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA; Hari Kumar contributed reporting from New Delhi for this article

multimedia.caption: In Rural India, a Vision of Stars
multimedia.credit: Anupam Kumar, a 17-year-old from a destitute corner of India, dreams of getting into a top college and going to work for NASA.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Anupam Kumar, a 17-year-old from a destitute corner of India, dreams of getting into a top college and going to work for NASA.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: In Rural India, a Vision of Stars

results.lead_paragraph: ANUPAM KUMAR, 17, is the eldest son of a scooter-rickshaw driver. He lives in a three-room house made of bricks and mortar and a hot tin roof, where water rarely comes out of the tap and the electricity is off more than on, along a narrow unpaved alley here in one of India's most destitute corners. Anupam is good at math. He has taught himself practically everything he knows, and when he grows up he wants to investigate whether there is life in outer space. He wants to work at NASA.

headline.main: A Trip Forward in Time. Your Travel Agent: Einstein.

results.snippet: Einstein's theory of relativity changed everything about the idea of time travel.
results.lead_paragraph: When H.G. Wells published his epochal novel ''The Time Machine'' in 1895, time travel was outlawed by the laws of physics. But that was Newtonian physics, and everything changed 10 years later with Einstein's theory of relativity. That theory -- which ushered in the age of E=mc2 and set the speed of light, 186,000 miles per second, as the cosmic speed limit -- allows for time travel to the future, physicists say. Here's how:

results.abstract: Advisory panel announces that NASA has not met three crucial safety recommendations it agreed to fulfill before returning shuttle fleet to orbit, although conclusions do not necessarily mean another delay for mission of Discovery, scheduled to launch as soon as July 13; recommendations include eliminating all debris from shuttle's external tanks, completing more precise analysis of risks of debris to shuttle and ensuring ability to repair damage in orbit; findings are embarrassment for NASA, although panel emphasizes that agency has significanty improved safety in last two years; says they are making no recommendations as to whether it is time for shuttle to fly again, and will present conclusions to new adminstrator Michael D Griffin (M)

headline.main: Panel Says NASA Falls Short on Safety

results.snippet: The findings are an embarrassment for NASA after two years of work to fix the problems that led to the loss of Columbia.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Warren E. Leary contributed reporting for this article

multimedia.caption: More Shuttle Problems
multimedia.credit: An advisory panel led in part by Richard O. Covey said that NASA has not met three crucial points, but Discovery may still lift off.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: An advisory panel led in part by Richard O. Covey said that NASA has not met three crucial points, but Discovery may still lift off.

results.lead_paragraph: NASA has not fully met three crucial safety recommendations it agreed to fulfill before returning the shuttle fleet to orbit, an advisory panel to the space agency said on Monday. The conclusions do not necessarily mean another delay for the mission of the Discovery, scheduled to launch as early as July 13. The agency is to decide on a launching date after a final ''flight readiness review'' later this week.

headline.main: Despite Concerns, NASA Is Planning to Go Ahead With Shuttle Launching

results.snippet: NASA's advisory panel said the agency had not fulfilled all the safety goals it had pledged to meet before returning its fleet to orbit.
results.lead_paragraph: NASA got some unexpected and unsettling news on Monday, when its own advisory panel said the agency had not fulfilled all of the safety goals it had promised to meet before returning the shuttle fleet to orbit. But it is planning to go ahead anyway, launching the Discovery in as little as two weeks. ''I think, based on what I know now, we're ready to go,'' Michael D. Griffin, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, told the House Science Committee yesterday. It may sound like a recipe for trouble, or worse, especially since the work left undone includes three of the most critical recommendations of the board that investigated the loss of the Columbia in 2003, including elimination of the kind of launch debris that doomed the Columbia and the development of on-orbit repair techniques.
